awd_titl_txt: CC* Data: ImPACT - Infrastructure for Privacy-Assured compuTations
awd_abstract_narration:
This project addresses one of the fundamental problems in distributed computing: the ability to compute on sensitive or private data in a secure manner.  This is critically important for multi-institution and cross-disciplinary sharing and analysis of data, particularly in health-related fields and the social sciences.  This project builds upon and enhances several cyberinfrastructure elements which have been developed through other NSF awards and are already part of the existing research base.  By developing methods for securely sharing private data in different collaborative settings, ImPACT (Infrastructure for Privacy-Assured CompuTations) lowers the barriers to using privacy-restricted data in scientific collaborations. It reduces the time to discovery and opens new avenues for research.

ImPACT enables a variety of research scenarios that require integration of data across subdomains where relevant data sets are held by different stakeholders. The goal of ImPACT is to enable cooperative processing across the stakeholder-owned datasets, while respecting the privacy policies of the individual owners, and to provide a model for collaboration that could be readily used by other institutions.  The project brings together a team that includes social science researchers, cyber-infrastructure experts, and distributed systems and security experts from the University of North Carolina, Duke University, and Indiana University. A non-profit organization formed by the city of Durham, NC provides some of the data sets that are used in the project. To enable end-to-end data flows, ImPACT builds upon prior investments by the NSF Campus Cyberinfrastructure program at the Duke and UNC campuses, as well as the Global Environment for Network Innovations (GENI) program to support straightforward transfers of data within the respective virtual infrastructures.  By supporting three different trust models between collaborators, the project develops diverse methodologies with best practices in networking, data management, security, and privacy preservation to accommodate a variety of collaborative scenarios. Data access, sharing, processing, and publishing are integrated into privacy-aware systems that allow scientists to use their own tools and that build upon enabling cyberinfrastructure technologies like Dataverse, CyVerse, and the Open Resource Control Architecture (ORCA) control software.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

inst.inst_name: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
inst.org_lgl_bus_name: UNIVERSITY OF NORTH CAROLINA AT CHAPEL HILL

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill

por.por_cntn:
The ImPACT project brought together researchers from the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, Duke University and Indiana University to develop technologies and approaches that would simplify the sharing and analysis of restricted data in a multi-university project setting. Researchers today dealing with private or restricted data struggle to obtain the data and perform discoveries on it due to onerous, often very manual and lengthy procedures of handling the data. The problem complexity rises exponentially when multiple data sets and researchers from multiple institutions are involved in the same project. Solving this problem would speed up discovery in a large number of disciplines, having an overall accelerating effect on many kinds of research.

 

The architecture developed by the ImPACT project team addresses the common problems that arise from the need to securely store, control access to and process privacy-restricted data in a multi-institutional, multi-stakeholder setting. Specifically the architecture includes several components—a way to publicly advertise a limited set of data attributes without exposing the sensitive data itself; a set of mechanisms for a data owner to specify and automatically enforce complex data-access policies commonly expressed today as DUAs (formal Data Use Agreements); a way to securely collect digital attestations from multiple stakeholders to satisfy those policies; and a reproducible template to deploy secure processing enclaves in which groups of researchers can analyze the data in a way that complies with data owner policies using the tools of their choice. 

 

The project team developed the architecture and the prototype implementation for each component defined in the architecture. The prototype was then evaluated in several real-world deployment scenarios. ImPACT team collaborated with a number of social scientists in order to glean the main pain points and requirements of operating with restricted and private data and to evaluate the prototype. The prototype, through a collaboration with Harvard University’s IQSS (Institute for Quantitative Social Science), integrates with Dataverse - a premier federated academic data repository system used by many science teams to store and advertise their data. 

 

The team made numerous presentations at scientific conferences and published several papers in well-established conferences and journals (ICCN, Elsevier’s Future Generation of Computing Systems or FGCS) describing their findings. There is continuing work by the team to adopt the ImPACT implementation at several universities as part of their effort to reduce the friction for researchers dealing with private or restricted data.


Last Modified: 08/16/2022
Modified by: Ilya Baldin
